The emission of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) from the coal-fired power plants poses a huge threat to human health and natural environment. The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (SCR) has been proven to be a mature technology for the abatement of NO x . To be the crucial component, the performance of the catalysts plays a determined role during the deNO x process. Fe2O3-based catalysts, as one of the most effective catalysts for SCR, have been comprehensively researched and fruitful results are achieved. Therefore, the advances in the applications of Fe2O3-based catalysts for NO x reduction was overviewed in this work. Simply put, the fundamentals of Fe2O3, such as this metal oxide's crystal structures and the corresponding preparation methods, were first introduced. After that, the physicochemical features and deNO x performances of various catalysts, including virgin Fe2O3, Fe2O3-supported, and Fe2O3-containing mixed oxide systems, were summarized. Considering the variable flue gas conditions in coal-fired power plants, the effects of the typical components of SO2, HCl, H2O, and fly ash on the catalyst's NO x reduction activity were also evaluated and the results demonstrated that with proper modification, catalyst flue gas component adaptability could be availably improved. Furthermore, the possible NO x reduction pathways over the Fe2O3-based catalysts under various conditions were discussed with the key intermediates and the rate-controlling stages clarified. Finally, suggestions were raised that attention needed to be concentrated on developing new Fe2O3-based catalysts that was capable of stably operating in real coal-fired flue gas in following research. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fe2O3-based catalysts Selective catalytic reduction Mechanisms NO x Gas components Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction NO x , the major air pollutant, poses a great threat to the environment and human beings [1]. Among the various industries, the produced NO x mainly comes from the combustion of fossil fuels in power stations. Faced with this environmental problem, the United States stipulated that the NO x emission limit of power stations must be set as 135 mg/m3. Meanwhile, a national standard named "Emission standard of air pollutants for thermal power plants" (GB 13,223–2011) was issued to restrict the NO x emission concentration to be lower than 100 mg/m3 in China [2]. Afterwards, a more stringent standard called the ultra-low emission standard was enforced in 2014 with the NO x emission concentration further restricted below 50 mg/m3 in China [3]. In order to meet these regulations, effective NO x abatement technologies should be employed. The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is a mature technology for the abatement of NO x [[4],[5]]. As the predominant component in this technique, the performance of the catalysts primarily determines the NO x removal efficiency of the entire power plant system [6]. V2O5 supported on WO3- or MoO3-promoted TiO2, forming the V2O5-WO3/TiO2, is the commercialized catalyst in industry [7]. Given that the content of V2O5 is optimized and some reactive metal oxides are introduced, NO x can be effectively reduced to N2 and H2O in the medium-high temperature region, and a relatively high N2 selectivity, along with an improved anti-poisoning ability, can also be obtained [8]. However, the toxic properties of V2O5, the high oxidation rate of SO2, and the relatively narrow operation temperature window restrain the further application of this catalyst system in future (Table 1 ) [9]. Therefore, developing an alternative catalyst with high activity and environmental friendliness is an urgent task in recent decades. As the substitutes for V2O5-WO3/TiO2 system, some other transition metal oxides, such as Fe2O3 [10], MnO2 [11–13], and CeO2 [14,15], have been systematically explored for the SCR reactions owing to the merits of low cost, adaptable micro-structures, superior thermal stability, and certain anti-poisoning ability. Once coupled with other materials, a satisfactory low-temperature NO x removal performance can be achieved for the MnO2-based catalysts and NO x can be effectively eliminated in the medium-high temperature region for the other two systems (Table 1) [16–19]. Moreover, the poor SO2-resistant ability, the main disadvantage of these three metal oxide-based catalysts, can be improved in a certain extent and the drawback of the relatively low N2 selectivity belonging to the MnO2-containing system can also be somehow overcome [16]. Among these metal oxides, Fe2O3 is attracting considerable attention; variable reactive oxygen species, easy formation of surface vacancies, satisfactory acid properties, environmental friendliness, and earth abundance enable this metal oxide suitable for the SCR process [20]. For elevating the performance of Fe2O3, diverse strategies, including chemical substitution and synthesis process optimization, were employed [10,21,22]. Once Fe2O3 was adopted as the active components [23], promoters [24], supports [25], or one component in multi-nary mixed oxides [26], a wide operation temperature window would always be established. In accordance with these advantages, a booming trend in the exploration of Fe2O3-based materials for NO x reduction process appears and in internationally famous journals, a large number of papers covering the aspects of catalyst deNO x performance, anti-poisoning behaviors, and reaction pathways are published. Thanks to these fruitful results, Fe2O3-based materials are undoubtedly the promising catalysts in practical applications. And notably, this knowledge would lay a solid foundation for the effective NO x emission reduction. In this review, we summarized the progress on the Fe2O3-based catalysts used for the SCR reactions. On the basis of the fact that Fe2O3 possesses diverse crystal phases, the corresponding information was introduced at first with the overview of their preparation techniques accompanying. And then, NO x reduction efficiency of various Fe2O3-based catalysts, such as virgin Fe2O3, supported Fe2O3, and Fe2O3-containing mixed oxides, were summarized. With the exception of N2, O2, NO x , and NH3, SO2, HCl, and fly ash also constitute the main components in coal-fired flue gas. Considering their potential interactions with the active species, these impacts on the catalysts' deNO x performance were discussed in the subsequent section. Given the elucidation of the possible SCR reaction pathways over the catalysts, the central intermediates, along with the rate-controlling stages, would also be clarified, results of which were capable of aiding in the design of new highly-active catalysts. At last, it was concluded with the suggestions that attention needs to be concentrated on developing new Fe2O3-based catalysts that is capable of stably operating in real flue gas environments in the future research. Fundamentals of Fe2O3 To date, four crystalline polymorphs of Fe2O3, namely, α-Fe2O3, β-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3, and Ɛ-Fe2O3, have been reported and described, among which α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3 could be found in nature while β-Fe2O3 and Ɛ-Fe2O3 were only available in the laboratory [27]. In general, α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3 were widely used in energy and environmental fields. Thus, the crystal information and the corresponding preparation methods of these two Fe2O3 materials were extensively overviewed in this section. Crystal information of Fe2O3 α-Fe2O3, also called ferric oxide, iron sesquioxide, and red ochre, was regarded as the oldest discovered iron oxides and widespread in rocks and soils. It had typical hexagonal crystal structure comprised of iron atoms with six oxygen atoms surrounded (Fig. 1 (a)) [28]. Notably, iron and oxygen atoms in α-Fe2O3 were arranged in a corundum structure, which was a trigonal-hexagonal scalenohedral with space group R 3 ¯ c and parameter lattices of 5.0356 nm (a) and 13.7489 nm (c), respectively [29]. And in per unit cell, there contained six formula units. O2− in α-Fe2O3 was arranged along the [001] plane of a hexagonal close-packed lattice and Fe3+ in the [001] basal planes occupied two-thirds of the octahedral interstices with the tetrahedral sites free from occupation [30]. This arrangement finally generated pairs of FeO6 octahedrons, where the edges were shared by three adjacent octahedrons in the same plane and one face with an octahedron in a neighboring plane in the [001] direction. The ligancies of Fe and O were six and four, respectively [28]. γ-Fe2O3, which possessed a cubic crystal structure of an inverse spinel type and crystallized in the P4132 space group with a parameter lattice of 0.8351 nm, was the second most common Fe2O3 polymorph in nature (Fig. 1(b)) [31]. Like Fe3O4, γ-Fe2O3 contained cations in tetrahedral (A) and octahedral (B) positions. Differing from Fe3O4, the crystal structure of γ-Fe2O3 featured vacant cation sites usually occurring in octahedral positions to compensate for the increased positive charge. That is to say, the stoichiometry of γ-Fe2O3 could be formally labeled as FeA(Fe5/3□1/3)BO4 [32]. Depending on the extent and nature of the ordering of the vacancies in octahedral sites, at least three different crystal γ-Fe2O3 symmetries were reported: (1) a cubic vacancy-disordered structure (Fd 3 ¯ m) where the vacancies were randomly distributed, (2) a cubic vacancy-ordered structure (P4343 and P4132) presenting a partially ordered vacancy pattern, and (3) a tetragonal structure with a threefold doubling along the c-axis, perfectly ordered vacancies (P43212) and lattice parameters of 0.8349 (a) and 2.4996 nm (c) [27]. Synthesis of Fe2O3 α-Fe2O3 Hydrothermal, hydrolysis, heat-reflux, and sol-gel approaches can be employed to successfully prepare α-Fe2O3. Hydrothermal technique is commonly employed to synthesize nano-materials possessing certain morphology and satisfactory dispersity. During the hydrothermal process, H2O is always used as the solvent; the precise control of the material growth can be realized by adapting the reaction conditions. Thanks to the above-mentioned merits, hydrothermal method is gaining considerable attention for preparing α-Fe2O3 materials. In 1997, Anand prepared hematite particles using the hydrothermal method at different pH values ranging between 3 and 10 [33]. As the pH value of precipitation increased, the size and the polycrystallinity of the particles exhibited a trend of decline; almost all the Fe2O3 particles presented single crystalline nature as the pH value was raised to 10. Wang took K3[Fe(CN)6] as the ferric source and used the hydrothermal method to synthesize α-Fe2O3 micro-pine dendrites [34]. Given that the hydrothermal temperature rose from 140 °C to 200 °C, the micro-topology of the resulting products changed from hyperbranched dendrites to nanorod-branched ones. And with increasing the concentration of the precursor, the branches became thicker. With the guidance of the surfactant NP-9, α-Fe2O3 molecules had more probability to attach onto the six equivalent facets of the initial crystals simultaneously. As a result, micro-snowflakes were identified as the main products [35]. Similarly, Yu found that as the molar ratio of Fe3+/PO4 3− ranging between 10 and 35, the "nucleation-aggregation-recrystallization" process was proceeded. That is to say, in this range, PO4 3− functioned as the ligand to be selectively adsorbed onto the facets parallel to the [001] zone and promoted the aggregation through the oriented attachment process with the Ostwald ripening accompanying. Consequently, α-Fe2O3 spindles were obtained. Given that the Fe3+/PO4 3− molar ratio was centered in the range of 35–40, the "nucleation-aggregation-dissolution-recrystallization" process mainly explained the presence of α-Fe2O3 nanorings, nanosheets, and nanospheres (Fig. 2 ) [36]. Apart from the above-mentioned one-step strategy, two-step approach was also adopted in some cases, where FeOOH, the main intermediate, was firstly synthesized using the hydrothermal method and after the calcination process, final product of α-Fe2O3 was in turn obtained. On the basis of this idea, α-Fe2O3 nanorods and nanoplates were successfully prepared [37–41]. And compared with the bulk materials, the as-obtained α-Fe2O3 nanorods even presented weakly ferromagnetic characteristics at low temperature and superparamagnetic property at room temperature [37]. When using the hydrolysis method to prepare α-Fe2O3 materials, FeCl3 was always utilized as the precursor. Sometimes in the absence of any precipitants, FeOOH, the intermediate, or α-Fe2O3, the final product, could be obtained. Based on the ideas concerning the aggregation of the preformed primary α-Fe2O3 and the re-precipitation of the ionic species through the dissolution of the preformed FeOOH particles, α-Fe2O3 particles were successfully prepared [42]. It was found that the hydrolysis process was a fast polymerisation behavior. The intermediates in this reaction were poorly crystalline Fe(III)-oxyhydroxy salts and a range of ferrihydrites with various crystallinity and magnetic ordering behaviors. Parameters of pH, OH− addition rate, and temperature, were important to the nature of these intermediates [43]. Based on these results, Ishikawa discovered that the introduction of Ti(IV) was able to lower the pH value of the solution, which impeded the hydrolysis of Fe(III). By contrast, given that metal cations of Cr(III) and Cu(II) were present in the FeCl3 solutions, no noticeable effects on the formation of FeOOH particles were exerted, which might be originated from the negligible changes in the pH value of the solution after adding these additives [44]. When phosphate anions were selected as the pH regulator, the morphology of α-Fe2O3 was transformed from nanospheres (100–300 nm) to nano-ellipsoids with the aspect ratio increasing to ∼10 [45]. Similar phenomena were found by Yin that in the solution system of virgin H2O, FeOOH nanorods with the diameters and lengths of ∼90 nm and 300 nm were resulted in [46]. Given that HCl was introduced as the additive, the aspect ratios of the products increased from ∼3.12 to ∼29.80. Upon the calcination process at higher temperatures, dehydrogenation reaction proceeded and α-Fe2O3 nanorods with similar dimensions would be obtained. Besides, Yin also found that elevating the hydrolysis temperature to 87 °C would contribute to the declined dimensions of FeOOH nanorods to 110 nm × 70 nm [47]. Apart from the above-mentioned two methods, sol-gel and heat reflux approaches were also employed to synthesize α-Fe2O3. However, some drawbacks, including the low yield of the final products and the limited availability of the precursors, restricted the wide application of these two techniques. Therefore, developing an alternative method to controllably synthesize α-Fe2O3 materials with a relatively high yield and uniform micro-topology still constitutes the research hotspot all over the world. γ-Fe2O3 Similar with α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3 can also be prepared using the hydrothermal, precipitation, and reflux techniques. Zhu took ferric chloride as the iron source with ethylene glycol acting as the solvent and reductant. With the guidance of NaOH and SDBS, hierarchically nanostructured hollow spheres assembled by nanosheets were obtained after the hydrothermal process. After calcination at 300 °C in air, γ-Fe2O3 hollow spheres were successfully prepared [48]. In the case of γ-Fe2O3 synthesized using the precipitation method, certain amounts of ferric and ferrous salts were employed as the precursor. With the guidance of the precipitant, such as NaOH and ammonia hydroxide, black intermediates were produced. Given the calcination at an intermediate temperature point, brownish particles of γ-Fe2O3 were finally obtained [49]. For the reflux method, organic solvent was always used to provide a high-temperature environment. At the same time, capping ligands would be supplied by the organic solvent or the added surfactants, which were subsequently anchored onto the particle surface and made the as-prepared material highly dispersed in certain solvents [50,51]. On the basis of this idea, γ-Fe2O3 particles with the size of ∼5 nm and γ-Fe2O3 nanorods were successfully prepared [52,53]. Based on the afore-mentioned results, Fe2O3 materials with various dimensions can be successfully synthesized through employing the appropriate experimental conditions. The characteristics of the prepared Fe2O3 nano-materials, such as the uniform size and micro-morphology, would provide a theoretical basis for investigating the structure-performance relationships of the catalysts and digging out the potential reaction pathways. DeNO x performance of Fe2O3-based catalysts The reported Fe2O3-based SCR catalysts are generally clarified into four categories, namely the pristine Fe2O3 catalyst, the supported Fe2O3 catalyst, the Fe2O3 supporting component catalyst, and the mixed oxide catalyst. Given that the synthesis parameters were appropriately optimized or the proper foreign components were introduced, a relatively high deNO x efficiency could always be obtained in a certain temperature range. In this section, the performance of the afore-mentioned typical catalysts were summarized (Table 2 ). Pristine Fe2O3 catalysts Among the various types of Fe2O3-based catalysts, pristine Fe2O3 was the simplest one for NO x reduction. Based on the density functional theory (DFT) analysis results from Du, the relatively low LUMO and hydrogenation energies demonstrate that Fe2O3 possesses a satisfactory redox ability and acid property, which is capable of assuring the adsorption and appropriate activation of NH3 during the NH3-SCR reaction (Fig. 3 ) [81]. These features endow virgin Fe2O3 with certain deNO x activity. Among the variable factors, crystal form is realized as an important one to determine the catalyst activity. As is mentioned above, γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3 are the most commonly used in catalysis. Shen compared the deNO x performance of the aforementioned two Fe2O3 materials and found that Fe-terminated surfaces in α-Fe2O3 only provided ferric sites for the adsorption of NO and NH3 with neighboring oxygen anions for their activation lacking, while the co-existence of iron and oxygen ions was able to jointly accomplish the adsorption and activation of NO and NH3, which contributed to an improved deNO x activity for γ-Fe2O3; the temperature window for 80% NO x conversion covered from 200 to 400 °C [53]. Li also claimed that both NH3 and NO x species were adsorbed and reacting easily on γ-Fe2O3, which mainly explained its better SCR performance than α-Fe2O3 [20]. Apart from the crystal forms, the preparation methods also influenced the activity of the catalysts. Compared with the catalyst prepared using the co-precipitation technique, γ-Fe2O3 synthesized via the facile method had a larger specific surface area, a higher concentration of reactive surface adsorbed oxygen, and an increased amount of acid sites, which were beneficial for the adsorption and activation of the reactants and subsequently enabled this sample with an increased deNO x efficiency [82]. Calcination temperature, an important parameter during the sample preparation stages, also holds a central role to play in the physicochemical properties and NO x removal performances of the catalysts. Chen synthesized a series of nanoporous hematite through the calcination of α-FeOOH at different temperatures (400, 500, 600, 700, and 800 °C) [83]. It was found that with an increment in the calcination temperature, the surface area, the average pore size, and the amount of adsorbed NH3 and surface oxygen defects were continuously decreased, which made the catalyst deNO x performance exhibit a tendency of decline. On the basis of the previously-indicated reports, one conclusion can be drawn that some chemical features, namely the acidity and the oxidizability, are predominantly important to the deNO x activity of the catalysts. However, for the catalysts with the formula of single metal oxide, the optimization of the synthesis stages can only contribute to the limited improvement in the physicochemical properties. To address this problem, coupling with some foreign metal oxides forming multi-nary metal oxide catalysts seems to be an appropriate approach because of the synergistic effects among the existing components, which are capable of optimizing the physicochemical qualities of the catalysts and hence have a promotional impact on NO x reduction. In this case, Fe2O3 could be utilized as the active agent, support or even one component belonging to the mixed oxides. Supported Fe2O3-based catalysts Even though virgin Fe2O3 presented certain catalytic activity, yet the limited physicochemical properties made certain adverse impacts on the dispersity and reactivity of the active sites, which subsequently restrained the effective elimination of NO x from the simulated flue gas. To overcome this drawback, Fe2O3 was sometimes used as the active species supported on the carriers. On the basis of its loading amount, Fe2O3 is present in various existing forms. Given that its loading amount is at a comparably low level, Fe2O3 prefers to be amorphous in structure. With its loading amount exceeding the theoretical monolayer coverage on the support surfaces, Fe2O3 crystallites start to be present. Support, the main component in this catalyst system, should possess the following three merits so that a satisfactory NO x conversion can be obtained. Firstly, a support should own a comparably large specific surface area so that the dispersity of iron species can be maximized and its aggregation behavior would thus be avoided. Secondly, a superior thermal stability should be needed so that the supported active species can be well stabilized. Thirdly, a certain anti-poisoning ability is also essential for the protection of active species from being deactivated. Among the various materials, zeolites, ZrO2, carbon, and TiO2 are recognized as the main appropriate support materials for the SCR catalysts. In this section, the advances in the development of Fe2O3/zeolite, Fe2O3/ZrO2, Fe2O3/carbon, Fe2O3/TiO2, and other supported Fe2O3 catalysts would be introduced. Fe2O3/zeolite-based catalysts To be a typically used support in environmental field, zeolites exhibit attractive advantages of low cost, high stability, simple modification process, superior anti-poisoning ability, unique textural structures suitable for adsorption and catalysis, and broad operating temperature range. Comprehensive researches demonstrated that zeolite-based catalysts could be a potential candidate for the practical applications, especially for the selective reduction of NO x from the flue gasses. Although virgin zeolite material possesses plentiful acid sites, yet the lack of the sites with redox behaviors restrains the effective removal of NO x from the simulated flue gas. In accordance of the satisfactory oxidizability of Fe2O3, loading this metal oxide onto zeolite surfaces might form a novel SCR catalyst. The types of zeolites would predominantly influence the existing forms of the active species, which subsequently bring out different catalytic performances. Iwasaki discovered that with the increase in the Si/Al2 ratio, fewer Bronsted acid sites could be available for the formation of active ion-exchanged Fe sites, which functioned as the active sites for the reduction of NO x [84]. And catalyst's SCR activity was closely related to the types of zeolites used, which followed the order of BEA>MFI>FER>LTL>MOR and might be attributed to the number of active Fe sites. Hong compared the NH3-SCR performance of the supported Fe2O3 catalysts using different zeolite materials with similar Si/Al and Fe/Al ratios (8.9–12 and 0.35–0.37, respectively) [54]. Given that UZM-35 was utilized as the carrier, iron species were primarily present in the form of isolated extra-framework Fe3+ ions, which explained the higher lower-temperature activity of Fe-UZM-35 than the catalysts using beta, LTA, and SSZ-13 zeolites as the supports (Fig. 4 ). It is generally understood that the loading amount of active species is a central factor to influence the catalyst's NO x conversion efficiency. In 2009, Fehrmann found that compared with conventional ion exchange and isomorphous substitution techniques, using the wet impregnation method to prepare Fe-HBEA catalyst would lead to a relatively high content of Fe, exhibiting over 90% NO x conversion from 300 to 550 °C [55]. Given that the content of Fe was set as 3 wt%, catalyst SCR activity reached the peak value. Similar results were obtained by Kureti that a volcano-shaped activity profile was presented as the content of Fe2O3 was raised [85]. Given that 0.25 wt% Fe2O3 was loaded, a relatively high proportion of isolated Fe oxo sites ensured a pronounced performance. At 200 °C, the turnover frequency of 0.25Fe/HEBA (8.5 × 10−3 s − 1) was much higher than that of commercial Fe-exchanged BEA (0.99 × 10−3 s − 1) and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (1.0 × 10−3 s − 1). Apart from the chemical components, the preparation conditions also constitute an important factor to determine the SCR activity of the catalysts. Through changing the preparation method, the roles of different iron species in deNO x activity of Fe-HEBA were clearly clarified [86]. Nitrate species, Fe2+ mononitrosyls [Fe2+(NO)], and Fe2+ dinitrosyls [Fe2+(NO)2] were found to be co-adsorbed onto the catalyst surfaces. For the sample synthesized using the liquid ion exchange methods, more Fe2+ mononitrosyls [Fe2+(NO)], the key intermediates in the SCR reactions, were prone to being formed, which mainly explained this catalyst's superior catalytic activity. During the Fe2O3 loading process, urea was used as the precipitant and as the molar ratio of urea/Fe was 7, large Fe2O3 particles were formed, which was beneficial for the low-temperature reaction [87]. The H2 reduction process transformed some Fe2O3 into elemental Fe, weakening the inhibiting effect arising from NH3 and shifting the operation temperature window towards lower temperatures. With air passivation, some isolated Fe3+ ions and adsorbed oxygen species were generated on the catalyst surface, inducing more NH4 + to combine with the Bronsted sites and consequently further broadening the operation temperature window (Fig. 5 ). Li claimed that as the calcination temperature exceeded 850 °C, the specific surface area and the pore volume exhibited a drastically decreasing tendency [88]. Meanwhile, the quantity of Bronsted and Lewis acid sites were also diminished, which had an inhibitory effect on the adsorption of NH3. Furthermore, migration of iron ions out of ion exchange sites on the Fe/HEBA catalyst was also suppressed, which exerted an adverse impact on the formation of iron oxide clusters, the main active sites involved in the SCR reactions. All these factors contributed to the diminishing of the catalyst's deNO x activity. For Fe-SSZ-15 synthesized using one-pot hydrothermal method, the increment of the calcination temperature to 550 °C also led to the severe deactivation; <50% NO x conversion was generated within the whole explored temperature range (100–550 °C) [89]. With proper modification, such as doping foreign metal oxides or constructing specific micro-structures, deNO x performance of Fe2O3-based zeolites could be effectively elevated. CeO2, a typical rare earth metal oxide, is famous for its superior oxygen storage capacity and abundant surface capped oxygen species. Given that CeO2 was selected as a promoter, Fe2O3-based zeolites catalysts would be well modified. Through utilizing the excellent oxidative ability of CeO2, NH3-SCR activity of Fe-Beta catalyst was improved [90]. Similarly, as CuO, a transition metal oxides owning extraordinarily strong oxidizability, was introduced, the coupling of Fe3+ in zeolite framework, monomeric Fe3+, and isolated Cu2+ species contributed to the effective removal of NO x from the experimental gas with high N2 selectivity obtained in a wide temperature window [49]. Unlike the previously-mentioned studies, Qu had a layer of hydrophobic silicate coated onto Fe-ZSM-5 surface to form Fe-ZSM-5@silicate-1 core-shell structured catalysts [56]. During the silicate coating process, parts of Fe species in Fe-ZSM-5 core would be dissolved, re-crystallized, and finally embedded in the silicate shell, which enhanced the adsorptive ability of NO and constituted the main reason for improving the SCR performance of the catalysts. Moreover, the hydrophobicity of the coated silicate layer endowed this catalyst with an enhanced H2O-resistant ability. Based on this micro-topology, Qu replaced the hydrophobic silicate layer with CeO2/mesoporous silicate layer [57]. Similar with the idea from Li [90], NO can be efficiently oxidized to NO2, which caused the occurrence of "fast-SCR: process on Fe-ZSM-5 with the low and medial-temperature reaction rate consequently improved (Fig. 6 ). Notably, the high cost of the zeolite materials would reduce the economy of the system, thus restraining the practical application of this catalyst. Fe2O3/ZrO2-based catalysts ZrO2, a transition metal oxide with excellent thermal stability, intermediate acidity, and environmental friendliness, can also be employed as the catalyst support. Compared with bulk ZrO2, catalyst NO x conversion quintupled at 300 °C with nano-ZrO2 used as the support relying on its relatively large specific surface area of 150 m2/g [91]. Given the modification of ZrO2 with WO3 or SO4 2−, solid superacids were formed, which could ensure the sufficient adsorption of the reductant NH3. With 7.0 mol% WO3 was introduced, temperature for obtaining 90% NO x conversion declined from ca. 420 °C to ca. 270 °C and the turnover frequency of NO x per Fe atoms was found to be 35 × 10−5 s−1, demonstrating a satisfactory SCR catalytic performance [58]. Ren further found that adding WO3 was capable of enlarging the specific surface area of ZrO2 support, improving the active component dispersity, enriching the surface Fe3+ cations and chemisorbed oxygen species, and enhancing the redox capacity and surface acidity. These merits simultaneously promoted the redox cycle and the adsorption ability of NH3, thus enabling WO3-promoted Fe2O3/ZrO2 catalyst with nearly 100% NO x conversion and >90% N2 selectivity in a wide operation temperature window of 300–500 °C [92]. And compared with MoO3, the introduced WO3 also facilitated the formation of NO2, which was able to accelerate the reduction of NO x , thus presenting an elevated SCR activity [93]. To be different, Golunski investigated the role of Fe2O3 in inducing SCR activity of Fe2O3/WO3-ZrO2 catalysts [94]. After changing the loading amount of Fe2O3, 3wt% Fe/WO3-ZrO2 was found to be the most active material, which could achieve 80–85% NO x conversion between 440 and 550 °C. In this case, Fe3+ was considered to function as the "active" Lewis acid sites to activate NO x that had a pivotal role in the SCR reaction and increase the strength of the Bronsted acidity, which distinguished the Lewis acid sites with different reactivity (Fig. 7 ). As sulfated ZrO2 was employed as the carrier, catalyst NO x conversion remained above 90% between 300 and 450 °C, almost doubling compared with the sulfate-free ones [59]. Given the partial substitution of ZrO2 by TiO2, the interactions between these metal oxides would lead to much higher conversion of Fe3+ to Fe2+, which might break a charge balance and accelerate the adsorption of NH3 and the oxidation of NO to NO2 [60]. As the molar ratio of Ti/Zr was adjusted to 1/4, NO x conversion of >90% and N2 selectivity of nearly 100% were reached from 300 to 500 °C. Fe2O3/carbon-based catalysts Thanks to the advantages of high specific surface area, sufficient pore structures, and plentiful oxygen-containing functional groups, carbon materials are gaining increasing attention in the air pollutant abatement processes. On the basis of the high reactivity of Fe2O3 in the NO x reduction reactions, coupling carbon materials with Fe2O3 might also form a promising catalyst to reduce NO x to N2 in coal-fired flue gas. In 2009, Zhu modified carbon tube-in-tube nanostructures with highly active Fe2O3 nanoparticles using the in situ method [95]. With the reaction temperature rising from 150 to 200 °C, NO x conversion was greatly enhanced from 70% to 98%; further raising the reaction temperature to 250 °C, NO x conversion ran at 100%. Similarly, Qu had Fe2O3 nanoparticles loaded onto carbon nanotubes (CNTs) using the ethanol-assisted impregnation method [61]. Thanks to the excellent electron transfer property of CNTs, the supported iron oxides exhibited an enhanced redox behavior and the adsorption and activation of NO x were effectively improved, which explained the higher NO x conversion of Fe2O3/CNTS than virgin α-Fe2O3. However, it is regretted that the effect of Fe2O3 loading amount on the catalyst activity remained unclear in these studies. Sun found that virgin AC exhibited a poor SCR activity with NO x conversion staying below 30% between 120 and 240 °C. Given the loading of Fe2O3, catalyst NO x conversion exhibited a trend of increment; as the molar ratio of Fe/AC reached 1/10, catalyst's SCR activity was maximized [62]. Similar conclusions were drawn by Ge and Yin that the doping of appropriate amount of Fe2O3 was able to elevate the NH3-SCR activity of >40% NO x conversion within the temperature range of 120–240 °C relying on the redox behaviors of Fe3+/Fe2+ [96,97]. To obtain an improved SCR activity based on the existing Fe2O3/carbon system, some researchers introduced another metal oxide forming supported mixed oxide catalysts. Via the interactions among the components, extra acid sites and reactive oxygen species would be in turn produced, which was proven to be beneficial for the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO x . V2O5, MnO2, and Cr2O3, the typical transition metal oxides possessing novel acidity and oxidizability, were considered as the appropriate promoters to modify the Fe2O3/carbon catalysts. Compared with virgin Fe2O3- or V2O5-loaded catalysts, the co-introduction of these two metal oxides increased the NO x conversion to different extent [98]. With the doping of MnO2, catalyst deNO x activity also presented an upward trend. As the molar ratio of Fe/Mn reached 10:5, >90% NO x conversion was achieved from 180 to 240 °C, which effectively broadened the operating temperature window towards higher temperatures [62]. Similarly, the synergistic effect between Fe2O3 and Cr2O3 increased the catalyst specific surface area and the number of the sites with weak and medium-strong acidity [96]. That enabled Fe2O3- and Cr2O3-containing catalysts with a greatly enhanced deNO x ability compared with virgin Fe2O3- or Cr2O3-added ones. Through the DFT method, it was further confirmed that the coupling of Cr2O3 and Fe2O3 improved the binding capacity of Fe2O3/AC and Fe3O4/AC surfaces and the NH3 adsorption property [99]. In the meantime, adding Cr2O3 also suppressed the formation of the relatively inert chelating bidentate nitrates and reduces the activation energies for NO oxidation, which well explained the promoted deNO x reaction over Cr2O3-introduced catalyst surfaces (Fig. 8 ). In addition to the introduction of promoters, some researchers chose to modify the carbon carrier with some functional groups for regulating the FeO x species via the metal-support interactions. Ammonium persulfate oxygen-functionalization would endow the carbon materials with negative charge, which in turn had a great affinity to the positively-charged γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles and thus immobilized them highly dispersed on the carrier surface. That tailored the Fe valence and oxygen vacancy of FeO x , which contributed to the formation of active oxygen vacancy-coupled Fe2+. Meanwhile, the anchored oxygen-containing functional groups were capable of serving as the extra active sites for the adsorption and activation of NH3, which delivered a superior NO x conversion of >90% at 120–250 °C (Fig. 9 ) [63]. By the pre-oxidation treatment and the modification with N-surface groups, NO x conversion of >90% was realized for Fe2O3-loaded AC catalysts between 180 and 300 °C, similar with that of Mn/N-AC [100]. Moreover, a comparably low amount of N2O was produced over Fe/N-AC within the whole investigated temperature range, indicating a raised N2 selectivity compared with Mn/N-AC. However, it should be noted that as the reaction temperature rose to 300 °C, strong outlet CO2 signal could be detected, suggesting that the carbon carrier started to be oxidized by the catalysts and oxygen at a high- temperature region. That is to say, even if the proper modification was capable of elevating the catalyst NH3-SCR performance, yet the comparably low thermal stability somehow restrained the application of this system in the high-temperature environment. Therefore, possessing a satisfactory thermal stability is speculated to be a solvent to this problem. Fe2O3/TiO2-based catalysts Anatase TiO2, as the carrier of the commercialized V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts, has the merits of abundant Lewis acid sites, satisfactory thermal stability, and a certain anti-poisoning ability. To be the carrier of Fe2O3-based catalysts, Li found that Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst seemed to exhibit limited SCR activity between 250 and 500 °C, as is evidenced by the its relative low NO x conversion below 80% [23]. Given that TiO2 was sulfated, Fe2O3, the active species, was prone to being highly dispersed rather than forming large aggregates. In addition, the introduced sulfate anions would serve as the strong Bronsted acid sites, which were responsible for the adsorption of plentiful NH3 and drove most NH3 to play the role of the reductants to reduce NO x instead of being directly oxidized to NO x in the higher temperature region. That finally endowed sulfated Fe2O3/TiO2 catalysts with an improved high-temperature SCR activity. Similarly, heteropoly acids were also added to strengthen the acidity of Fe2O3/TiO2 so that the adsorption capacity of NH3 was enlarged, which consequently contributed to the improved activity [101]. Given that V2O5 was present, the combination of this metal oxide and Fe2O3 would form iron vanadate compounds, of which FeVO4 constituted the typical kind. As FeVO4 was loading onto TiO2 surface, the existing Fe3+-O-V5+ linkages with low coordination number of V atoms induced the presence of abundant surface defects for reactant adsorption and activation, and the electronic inductive effects between Fe3+ and V5+ suppressed the occurrence of the side reactions regarding NH3 oxidation [64]. Given an increase in the loading amount of FeVO4 to 9 wt%, over 90% deNO x efficiency was obtained at 250–400 °C. Upon the modification of TiO2 support with WO3, supported FeVO4 catalyst's low-temperature NO x conversion was further raised. Further investigation demonstrated that compared with FeVO4/TiO2, the greater electronic inductive effect of Fe2V4O13 enhanced the redox character as well as the amount of sites accessible to NO x /NH3, thus displaying an elevated deNO x performance [102]. Through adding Sb2O5, catalyst redox feature was continuously promoted, which facilitated the interactions with NH3/NO x and consequently outperformed Sb2O5-free one in the NH3-SCR processes. Upon the micro level, anatase TiO2 was always surrounded by the crystal facets of [001], [100], and [101], of which the average energy followed the order of [001] > [110] > [101] [65]. Zhang used HF solution as the structure-directing agent to successfully prepare anatase TiO2 nanosheets with highly active [001] facets exposed [65]. Taking the anatase TiO2 nanoparticles with chemically stable [101] facets surrounded as the reference, the exposure of [001] facets increased the amount of oxygen defects, acid sites, and adsorbed nitrate species. Additionally, energies for NH3 and NO adsorption onto TiO2 nanosheets were lower than that onto nanoparticle counterparts. Combined with the rapid electron transfer and regeneration of Fe3+ on TiO2-[001], an elevated deNO x activity was achieved. However, it was worth-noting that no matter how the exposed crystal facets were varied, the resulting materials were always regarded as the "bulk" TiO2. In contrast to this, the idea of developing amorphous TiO2 came out. Relying on its relatively large specific surface area, amorphous TiO2 also presented certain prospect in the SCR reactions. Via the surface grafting strategy, Dong constructed thin-layered titania confined in mesoporous silica. Through efficiently utilizing the merit of high surface area belonging to amorphous TiO2, an increased number of Bronsted acid sites were generated and the dispersion of Fe2O3 was also improved. In other words, the intense interaction of Fe-Ti brought out superior redox ability and strengthened acidity, thus favoring the proceeding of the SCR reactions [103]. Apart from the support micro-topology, improving the dispersity of active species also accounted for the enhanced catalytic performance, especially for the catalysts with relatively low loading of active components [104]. Li utilized an ethylene glycol (EG)-assisted impregnation method to synthesize the typically used low-temperature catalyst, Fe2O3 −MnO2/TiO2. With the guidance of EG, parts of Fe atoms would enter the lattice of TiO2; the formation of Fe-O-Ti structure with strong interaction strengthened the electronic inductive effect and increased the content of surface chemisorption oxygen, which contributed to an improvement in the oxidation performance of NO and completely overcame the drawbacks arising from the slightly declined surface acidity, hence favoring the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of EG-assisted catalyst via the "fast-SCR" process [66]. Other supported Fe2O3 catalysts Apart from the commonly used support materials mentioned above, other materials, such as CeO2, SiO2, and attapulgite, were also employed as the carrier to support Fe2O3 and most of the developed catalysts were proven to be active in the deNO x reactions. Zhang investigated the facet-dependent catalytic performance of Fe2O3/CeO2 catalysts for the SCR reactions [67]. It was discovered that Fe2O3/CeO2 nanorods with (110) and (100) facets exposed were more reactive to NH3 and NO gasses than the catalysts with chemically stable (111) facets exposed. As a result, Fe2O3/CeO2 nanorods exhibited a comparably broad operation temperature window. With SiO2 selected as the carrier, loading appropriate amount of Fe2O3 was able to have a significant improvement in the NO x conversion from 240 to 330 °C through the synergistic effect between Fe2O3 and MnO2 [68]. Owing to its rich channel for reactant gas adsorption, attapulgite (ATP) was widely used in the catalytic field, including the SCR reactions. MnO2-Fe2O3 [69], LaFeO3 [105], MnO2 CeO2-Fe2O3 [106], MnO2-Fe2O3-TiO2 [107], and LaFeMnO3 [108] mixed oxides were used as the active components to modify ATP. Relying on the synergistic effect between active species and support, the resulting catalysts always present superior deNO x activity in a certain temperature range. On the basis of the above analysis, the merits of the supports are primarily reflected in several aspects: (1) increasing the dispersity of Fe2O3 and making it amorphous; (2) providing sufficient acid sites and ensuring the efficient adsorption of the reductant; (3) adjusting the redox capacity of the catalysts through the electron transfer between Fe and other elements and thereby effectively suppressing the non-selective oxidation of NH3. Metal oxides supported on Fe2O3 catalysts Considering its acceptable thermal stability and novel oxidizability, Fe2O3 can also be a catalyst support to supply redox sites for the activation of NH3 and NO. When coupled with acidic components, a relatively high NO x conversion can still be resulted in. WO3, a typical metal oxide with excellent acidic behaviors, is popularly used as a promoter to modify the physicochemical properties of an SCR catalyst. Apparently, a satisfactory NO x removal efficiency can always be obtained. Liu prepared WO3/Fe2O3 catalyst using the conventional wet impregnation method and found that the maximum NO x conversion of virgin Fe2O3 was only 33% at 275 °C and even negative NO x conversion appeared above 350 °C. Given the introduction of WO3, a significant elevation in the SCR activity was observed. When the loading amount of WO3 reached 10%, over 90% NO x conversion was achieved in a wide temperature range of 275–425 °C [70]. This is because the added WO3 could lead to an elevated specific surface area, an increased number of Lewis acid sites for NH3 adsorption, and a proper redox property for NH3 activation. Similar phenomena were obtained by He that via the electronic inductive effect of W-O-Fe bonds, the oxidation ability of Fe(3+δ)+ species was improved with the over-oxidation of NH3 suppressed. Combined with the facilitated adsorption and activation of NH3 arising from the introduced abundant surface reactive acid sites by WO3, catalyst NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity were simultaneously improved [26]. Wang modified spindle-shaped Fe2O3 with CeO2 and WO3. It is found that the addition of CeO2 could facilitate the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and moderate basic sites; introducing WO3 was able to increase the number of Bronsted acid sites. The synergistic effect of WO3 and CeO2 on balancing acidity/basicity properties contributed to the high activity of Ce- and W-doped catalysts (Fig. 10 ) [109]. Similarly, the partial substitution of Fe2O3 by NiO could promote the formation of NiFe2O4, which, together with the impregnated WO3, suppressed the crystal growth of Fe2O3 and the collapse of the pore structures originated from the high calcination temperature. Furthermore, the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ via the electronic inductive effect between Fe and Ni cations increased the molar ratio of chemisorbed oxygen and Bronsted acid sites. This synergistic effect finally constituted the central reason for the higher NO x removal ability of NiO-modified WO3/Fe2O3 catalysts (Fig. 11 ) [71]. Some other acidic components, including MnO x and heteropolyacid, were also utilized as the promoters to optimize Fe2O3. Relying on its superior oxidative ability and acidic behavior, MnO x is accepted to be an ideal candidate for the modification of the catalysts. Li selected Mn2O3 and Fe2O3 hexagonal microsheets as the active agent and the support, respectively [72]. Given the optimization of the Mn2O3 loading amount, nearly 95% NO x conversion was reached in a temperature range of 150–300 °C. Gao introduced silicotungstic acid onto Fe2O3 surface to form H4SiW12O40/Fe2O3 composites. Given that proper amount of silicotungstic acid was doped, the operation temperature window of Fe2O3 was significantly broadened. Besides, an important conclusion was arrived at that the balance of the acid and the redox properties served as a key role in the deNO x activity of an SCR catalyst (Fig. 12 ) [25]. Wang also utilized tungstophosphoric acid to optimize the Fe2O3 nanoring catalyst and found that the synergistic interactions between these two components improved the thermal stability of HPW polyanions, which made a favorable NO x conversion remained at high temperatures and thus brought out a broad operation temperature window [110]. Recently, single-atom catalyst is gaining increasing awareness owing to the merits of the maximized dispersion of the active species, which would enhance the metal-support interactions and hence facilitated the proceeding of the reactions. Tang developed single-atom Mo/Fe2O3 and W/Fe2O3 catalysts by anchoring single acidic Mo or W ions on (001) surfaces of reducible α-Fe2O3 [111]. Through calculating the number of the anchoring sites on α-Fe2O3 surfaces, the maximum load capacity of Mo and W could be determined. Once single Mo or W atom was anchored, one dinuclear site containing one Mo/W ion and one neighboring Fe ion would be constructed. Given an increment in the dinuclear sites, catalyst SCR reaction rates increased linearly with the apparent activation energy remaining almost unchanged. This finding demonstrates that the synergistic effects between Fe and the added elements may cover the following aspects: (1) introducing extra acid sites onto the Fe2O3 surface and accommodating more NH3 for NO x reduction; (2) balancing the acid and redox properties of the catalysts and facilitating the proceeding of the selective NO x reduction reaction. Mixed oxide catalysts In accordance of the fact that the oxidizability served a predominant role in the deNO x activity of the catalysts, the introduction of foreign metal oxides into Fe2O3 forming Fe2O3 −MO x (Mn=V, Ti, W, et al.) mixed oxides appeared to constitute an appropriate approach to improve this chemical feature. It is also understood that vast variations in the valance states always exist between Fe and foreign metal atoms; the activation energy correlated to the formation of oxygen vacancies next to the dopants would be lowered [112]. In other words, oxygen could be more easily activated over the modified catalysts through the so-called "short-activation effect", which would somehow facilitate the proceeding of the catalytic reactions. Additionally, considering the fact that there also exist some differences in the diameters between Fe and foreign metal atoms, the introduction of foreign metal oxides would contribute to the distortion of Fe2O3 lattice, which somehow suppressed the growth of Fe2O3 crystals and in turn enlarged the surface area of the catalyst, thus further facilitating the SCR reactions to some extent. Such knowledge demonstrated that FeO x − MO x mixed oxide seemed to be a potentially effective catalyst for NO x reduction. Spinel-structured catalysts Spinel-structured oxides, with the chemical formula of AB2O4, are gaining considerable awareness owing to their special features as a catalyst. In the typical structure of a spinel oxide, O2− was located in pseudo cubic-close-packed spatial arrangement, in which 8 of the 64 tetrahedral interstices and 16 of the 32 octahedral interstices were successively occupied by A-site and B-sites cations, respectively [73]. Consequently, the large lattice parameter, the abundant oxygen vacancies, the cations transfer ability between A and B sites contributed to the outstanding performance of the spinel-type oxides [113]. Moreover, with the substitution of the cations at A or B sites, the spinel structure would be well maintained and the acid and redox qualities could be effectively adjusted, which might be consequently beneficial for the SCR reactions [114]. Fe3O4, a typical spinel-structured material, was found to be active in the SCR reactions. Given that appropriate foreign metal oxides were introduced, catalyst SCR performance can be optimized with its spinel structure well retained. Li took ferrous sulfate, ferric trichloride, and titanium tetrachloride as the precursors to synthesize (Fe3- x Ti x )1- δ O4 spinel-structured catalysts [21]. Through establishing the correlations between structure and performance, the SCR activity of (Fe3- x Ti x )1- δ O4 was found to be related to the oxidative ability of Fe3+ cations, the concentration of the adsorbed NH3, and the content of reducible Fe3+. Later, Liu used transition metal oxides of MnO x , CoO x , NiO x , and ZnO x to modify iron spinel oxides [73]. It was found that the doping of the latter three metal species into iron spinel structure inhibited the redox cycles of Fe3+/Fe2+, which hindered the activation of NH3. The doping of Mn led to the outmost surface coverage of Mn and maintained the maghemite-type spinel structure, which enabled Mn-added catalyst to exhibit high NH3-SCR activity. Furthermore, as 10% MnO2 was loaded, the rapid electron transfer between Mn4+ and Fe2+ accelerated the regeneration of Fe3+ and thus directly facilitated the activation of NH3, hence elevating the SCR performance of Fe-Ti catalyst, especially in the temperature region of <200 °C [115]. Other mixed oxide catalysts Given that ferrous salts were absent in the preparation stage, (Fe3- x Ti x )1- δ O4 spinel-structured materials would be transformed to common Fe2O3-TiO2 mixed oxide. In 2008, Liu found that this composite exhibited the NO x conversion of >95% from 225 to 350 °C [74]. Compared to the sample using TiCl4 as the precursor, catalyst selecting Ti(SO4)2 as the Ti precursor was identified to be favorable for the high NH3-SCR activity and N2 selectivity [116]. This was because the formed Fe-O-Ti structure functioned as the main active species and the interaction between these two species in atomic scale contributed to an enhancement in the oxidative ability of Fe3+. Based on this result, Liu also studied the influence of Fe/Ti molar ratio on the performance of Fe2O3-TiO2 catalyst [117]. Given that the molar ratio of Fe/Ti was fixed to 1:1, the formation of Fe-O-Ti bonds was facilitated, which maximized the amount of acid sites, the mobility of lattice oxygen, the oxidative ability of Fe3+, and the specific surface area. These merits endowed the catalyst with the Fe/Ti molar ratio of 1:1 with the highest intrinsic activity. Through increasing the calcination temperature, well crystallized pseudobrookite Fe2TiO5 appeared, which had a positive effect on the formation of reactive monodentate nitrate species and thus presented much higher intrinsic SCR activity with the normalization by the specific surface area [118]. Furthermore, Liu used MnO2 to substitute iron species in Fe2O3-TiO2 and found that the added MnO2 contributed to the structural distortion of the catalyst, which enlarged the surface area, enriched the surface acid sites, and increased the mobility of lattice oxygen [75]. As the molar ratio of Fe/Mn reached 1:1, NO x can be completely reduced in the temperature region of 225–350 °C. Based on the satisfactory compatibility of MnO2 and Fe2O3, Zhan and Wang synthesized MnO2-Fe2O3 binary mixed oxide catalyst for the NH3-SCR reactions [49]. Given that the molar ratio of Mn/Fe reached an appropriate value, a wide operation temperature window and a satisfactory N2 selectivity could be obtained. The synergistic effect between the introduced MnO2 and the existing Fe2O3 would boost the formation of Mn-O-Fe compounds, which increased the surface concentration of acid sites, and enhanced the redox properties and NO adsorption strength, thereby enabling MnO2-Fe2O3 mixed oxide catalyst with a satisfactory performance. Lu even used a serial metal oxides (CoO x , NiO x , AlO x , ZnO x , SnO x , CuO x , MgO) to modify α-Fe2O3 and discovered that compared with other metal oxides, the addition of CoO x was able to maximize the catalyst SCR performance [119]. Through optimizing the molar ratio of Co/Fe to 0.2, ∼100% NO x conversion was reached from 170 °C to 250 °C. This was because adding CoO x into α-Fe2O3 would promote the formation of CoFe2O4 crystals and increased the content of Fe3+ and surface oxygen, which led to higher activity of NO oxidation to NO2 and thus boosted the occurrence of "fast-SCR" reactions. In addition to the aforementioned metal oxides with strong oxidative ability (MnO2, CoO x , etc.), some other metal oxides with weak or intermediate oxidizability could also be an appropriate choice for catalyst modification. Zhang developed iron-vanadium mixed oxide catalysts and clarified that introducing vanadium oxide contributed to the enhanced acidity and redox ability, which enabled this system with a high NH3-SCR performance; from 225 to 400 °C, the optimized iron-vanadium mixed oxide presented a NO x conversion of >80% [120]. Li also found that as the molar ratio of Fe/V was set as 3/1, ∼100% NO x conversion from 175 °C to 400 °C was achieved [76]. This was because the electron inductive effect between Fe and V generated the charge depletion of Fe, which contributed to an improved redox ability and thus facilitated the oxidation of NO to NO2; the strong interaction between FeVO4 and Fe2O3 left V exist in a higher valence state, exerting a positive effect on the adsorption and activation of NH3. Nb2O5, in which the metal element was located in the same main group with V, exhibited some similar properties with V2O5, such as the novel acidity and certain oxidative ability. Based on the afore-mentioned satisfactory NH3-SCR performance of Fe2O3-V2O5 catalyst, the combination of Nb2O5 and Fe2O3 to form the Fe2O3 Nb2O5 binary mixed oxide catalyst should also effectively removal NO x from the simulated flue gas. He prepared a serial iron-niobium composite oxides using the CTAB-assisted co-precipitation method [77]. Given that the molar ratio of Nb/Fe was 0.4, catalyst exhibited superior SCR performance with NO x conversion exceeding 90% from 250 to 400 °C. The interaction between iron and niobium species not only induced more reducible iron species at low temperatures but also enhanced the surface acidity. That is to say, the adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO x were simultaneously enhanced, thereby bringing about a high NH3-SCR reactivity. Sb2O5, similar with Nb2O5, also possessed a strong acidity and was capable of being responsible for the accommodation of NH3. The combination of Sb2O5 with acid properties and Fe2O3 with redox behaviors were responsible for the >90% NO x conversion in the temperature range of 175–375 °C [78]. Considering the elevated SCR activity of Fe2O3 by modifying MgO found by Lu [119], Xu investigated the effects of Fe/Mg molar ratio and calcination temperature on the NH3-SCR performance of Fe2O3 −MgO mixed oxide [79]. It was found that as the molar ratio of Fe/Mg was set as 8/2, NO x conversion of >90% was achieved from 250 to 350 °C. Given that the catalyst was calcined at 400 °C, a relatively high surface area was obtained, suggesting the efficient interaction between catalyst and reactant. Besides, the generation of plentiful surface acid sites and reactive oxygen species ensured the facilitated adsorption and activation of the reactants. Considering the advantages of the single-atom catalysts, Sun synthesized a single-atom Ce-modified α-Fe2O3 (Fe0.93Ce0.07O x with 7% atomic percentage of Ce) catalyst through the citric acid-assisted sol-gel method [80]. With a relatively low amount of Ce was doped, the atomic dispersion of Ce species would be ensured and the generation of local Fe-O-Ce sites in the FeO x matrix could be boosted, which was discovered to be favorable for the oxidation of NO to NO2 and thus was beneficial for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x to N2. However, an increase in the addition amount of Ce species would result in the formation of CeO2 particles, which deteriorated the SCR activity of CeO2-Fe2O3 catalysts. Different from virgin Fe2O3 materials, interfaces always existed among the various components in the multi-nary composites, where atoms possessed unsaturated chemical bonds and exhibited the properties of charge imbalance. That would facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies and accelerate the activation of gaseous O2; the activated oxygen species were proven to be primarily responsible for the enhanced activation of the reactants, which somehow accelerated the selective reduction process of NO x . In combination with their relatively high surface area, multi-nary catalysts would be capable of effectively degrading NO x on certain occasions and presenting some application prospects. SCR reaction mechanisms It is understood that the adsorption of the reactant molecules onto the catalyst surface active centers is the beginning of the reactions. Thus, in this section, the adsorption behaviors of NH3 and NO, along with the corresponding active sites, would be first introduced. After that, the interactions between the as-formed intermediates would be illustrated, since these behaviors constitute the main steps in the reactions. And based on these results, the potential pathways could be systematically clarified. Adsorption of NH3 To be the first step in the SCR reactions, the adsorption behavior of NH3 onto the catalyst surface holds a predominant role in its NO x conversion rate. Based on the in situ DRIFTS method, the adsorbed ammonia species were always present in the forms of NH3 coordinated on the Lewis acid sites and NH4 + bonded to the Bronsted acid sites [49]. In this case, hydroxyl groups and unsaturated metal cations operated as the Bronsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [121]. The attributions of the NH3-related IR characteristic peaks are summarized in Table 3 . Through the DFT method, the octahedral Fe cations belonging to γ-Fe2O3(111) were found to attract more electrons from NH3 than the tetrahedral ones (Fig. 13 ). Combined with the lower adsorption energy of NH3 (−90.729 kJ/mol), the octahedral Fe cations were identified as the most active species to adsorb NH3 with Fe-N bonds formed [124]. Meanwhile, the formation of hydrogen bonds between H atom in NH3 and lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface also contributed to the adsorption of NH3. Similar results were also obtained by Gui that the octahedral Fe cation on γ-Fe2O3(001) was responsible for NH3 adsorption because of the low adsorption energy of −104.786 kJ/mol and the Mulliken charge change, together with the increased NH bond angle, confirmed the electron transfer from NH3 molecule to substrate [125]. Provided that oxygen defects existed, the adsorption energy of NH3 onto octahedral Fe cation would be further lowered [126]. When it comes to the α-Fe2O3(012) surface, which was terminated by three- and four-coordinated oxygen (O3c and O4c) and five-coordinated unsaturated Fe cations (Fe5c), NH3 was prone to contacting with Fe5c in the form of coordinated NH3 instead of ionic NH4 + [127]. Given that Ce was doped, the adsorption energy of NH3 onto Fe cations declined, meaning that this behavior was some easier than that of virgin γ-Fe2O3(001) (Fig. 14 ). In the case of Fe1 that was located adjacent to Ce atom, the interactions between these two atoms would lead to the inhibited electron transfer from NH3 to Fe1, thereby somehow interfering with the adsorption of NH3 onto this site. On the contrary, for Fe2 and Fe3 that were comparably far away from Ce atom, more electrons would be received, hence making NH3 easily adsorb onto these two Fe sites [125]. Furthermore, as some other metals of Mn and Ti were introduced, the adsorption energy of NH3 onto α-Fe2O3(001) surface increased from 1.216 eV to 3.226 and 1.715 eV, indicating that adding these two metals promoted the adsorption of NH3 [128]. Conversely, the adsorption energy of NH3 onto Cr- and Ni-doped respectively declined to 0.536 and 0.850 eV, indicative of the inhibitory impacts. And surface metal cations lacking electrons were confirmed as the Lewis sites to receive electrons from lone pair orbits of N and thus accommodated NH3. Adsorption of NO To be another reactant in the SCR reactions, the adsorption of NO onto the catalyst surface also constitutes an important step. Through the DFT method, N atoms in NO preferred to be adsorbed onto both of the two Fe cations with nitrosoacyl compound formed (Fig. 15 ) [124]. The smaller radio of N atom and the shorter length of Fe-N bond enabled Fe-N with an increased stability. And compared with octahedral Fe, more electrons would be attracted when NO was adsorbed on the tetrahedral Fe, which aided in the formation of more stable chemical bond. Different with the NH3 adsorption site on γ-Fe2O3(111), tetrahedral Fe was primarily involved in the accommodation of NH3. For the γ-Fe2O3(001) configuration, once the NO molecule approached the catalyst surface, the N atom would bond with the octahedral Fe cation and O atom in NO would be resisted to get close to Fe sites because of the surrounded O anions, which confirmed the formation of Fe-N bond [126]. Similar results were obtained that over Ce-doped γ-Fe2O3(001) surface, N atom seemed to be prone to bonding with Fe cation owing to this configuration's low adsorption energy of −251.276 kJ/mol and electron transfer also took place from NO molecule to the substrate. Differing from the γ-Fe2O3(111) surface, stable chemical bond was still formed between NO and the octahedral Fe in this case [125]. When it referred to the α-Fe2O3(012) configuration, the opposite phenomena were observed that three coordinated oxygen, instead of unsaturated Fe cation, operated as the main sites for NO adsorption [127]. With the guidance of oxygen, the adsorbed NO would be converted to monodentate, bridging, and bidentate nitrates/nitrites, which would interact with the adsorbed NH3 and form some intermediates [123]. Apparently, based on in situ DRIFTS studies, the adsorbed NO species on the catalyst were always present in the forms of monodentate, bridging, and bidentate nitrates [129]. The thermal stability of these three adsorbed NO species followed the order of monodentate nitrate < bridging nitrate < bidentate nitrate [129]. The attributions of the NH3-related IR characteristic peaks were summarized in Table 4 . SCR reaction pathways Once NH3 was adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, the reactions between the adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NO or as-formed nitrates/nitrites would occur. Over α-Fe2O3(012) surface, NO would migrate from three-coordinated O atom (O3c) to five-coordinated unsaturated Fe atom (Fe5c) and then interact with the adsorbed NH3 forming NONH3 species. One H atom in NH3 would subsequently move to adjacent O3c with the intermediate of NH2NO and O3cH group formed. In other words, NH3 was activated into -NH2 at the Fe5c site, which then reacted with the desorbed NO from O3c forming NH2NO. After that, one H atom was transferred to O3c with NHNO species formed, which then isomerized into N2 and -OH. Finally, H atom from O3cH group moved to -OH to produce H2O molecule [127]. Identically, over γ-Fe2O3(001) surface, the adsorbed NH3 would dehydrogenated into NH2, which would combine with NO forming the intermediate of NH2NO (Fig. 16 ). Given the proceeding of another dehydrogenation process, NHNO species would be formed, which would dissociated to N2 and -OH. The released energy from the generation and desorption of N2 would ensure the combination of -OH with H atom from NH2NO to form H2O. Notably, this reaction pathway was dominant in the absence of O2 [130]. Similar conclusions were obtained that the reaction pathways of NH3 adsorption → NH3 dehydrogenation → NH2NO formation → NHNO formation → N2 and H2O formation was also capable of explaining the SCR reactions over Ce-doped γ-Fe2O3(001) surface with Fe site participating in the adsorption of NO and NH3 [125]. Given that O2 was present, the adsorbed NO would be oxidized to the intermediate of -ONO2 with the two products of NO2 and NO3 formed (Fig. 16) [130]. These two species were adsorbed onto Fe-top and hollow sites of the γ-Fe2O3(001) surface through Fe-O bond. Once NH3 was dehydrogenated to NH2, the as-formed NO2 would interact with this species forming NH2NO2, which continued to dehydrogenate into NHNO2. After the dissociation reaction, N2O was formed and then desorbed from Fe-top site or dissociated to N2. With the exception of DFT method, some experiments, such as transient reaction and in situ DRIFTS, were conducted to clarify the SCR mechanisms over Fe2O3-based catalysts. For the commonly used FeO x -TiO x binary mixed oxide catalyst, Liu found that both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites could be available for the SCR reactions [123]. NH3 primarily adsorbed on Ti sites as ionic NH4 + and coordinated NH3; the adsorbed NO on Fe sites was present in the form of monodentate nitrate. Given that the reaction temperature was below 200 °C, Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism dominated, in which forming monodentate nitrate, the reactive species, from NO oxidation constituted the rate-controlling step. On the contrary, the SCR reaction mainly followed the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism with the temperature exceeding 200 °C, in which the formation of NH2NO was the rate-determined stage. Similarly, monodentate nitrate was also discovered to be the reactive species during the SCR reactions while bidentate nitrate or bridging nitrate presented the inert properties over some other Fe2O3-based catalysts, which mainly constituted the l-H reaction pathways at lower temperatures [77,78,131]. And an increase in the temperature would inhibit the formation of monodentate nitrate, which cut down the l-H reaction pathways, hence leaving E-R mechanism dominating in the higher temperature region. Through the theoretical calculations, Yang found that over (Fe2.5Mn0.5)1- δ O4, both l-H and E-R mechanisms explained the SCR reactions [132]. At lower temperatures, the contribution of l-H mechanism was comparably predominant. Given an increase in the reaction temperature, the contribution of l-H pathways exhibited a tendency of decline. To be different, the contribution of E-R pathway to the SCR reaction seemed negligible at 80 and 120 °C over (Fe2.8Mn0.2)1- δ O4. With the temperature raised, the contribution of E-R mechanism appeared and increased. Poisoning behavior In general, N2 and O2 account for a large proportion (ca. 80%) in real coal-fired flue gas, whereas the remaining part (ca. 20%) consists of H2O, SO2, HCl, etc. Considering their high reactivity, these species would inevitably interact with the catalyst active centers and form relatively inert products, which interferes with the SCR reactions. Thus, in this section, the poisoning behaviors of these species on the catalysts would be clarified. SO2 SO2 remains a typical constitute in real coal-fired flue gas. In most cases, the concentration of SO2 in the flue gas is around several hundreds of ppm. Considering the fact that SO2 has a strong affinity to metal oxides, the impacts of this species on the SCR performance of Fe2O3-based catalysts were extensively investigated by researchers, for this knowledge is of great importance for the commercialization of this system. For virgin Fe2O3 particles, Gui found that purging 1000 ppm SO2 into the simulating flue gas resulted in a decline of the NO x conversion from 99.2% to 58% at 180 °C in 240 min [133]. Through the TGA and FTIR characterizations, the formation of metal sulfates and ammonium sulfates mainly caused the suppression of the catalyst activity. Yang also confirmed that purging 500 ppm SO2 into the reaction system also deactivated the γ-Fe2O3 catalyst, as evidenced by the shift of the operation temperature window about 100 °C towards higher temperatures [10]. In 2022, Sun used the experimental and DFT techniques to study the poisoning mechanisms of γ-Fe2O3 [134]. It was found that the reactivity of NH4 + was an essential factor to determine whether or not the ammonium bisulfate coverage effect worked and for γ-Fe2O3, the timely consumption of ammonium bisulfate was promoted by the boosted reaction between NH4 + and NO x . Therefore, the main reason for the severe sulfur deactivation was attributed to the formation of stable and inert metal sulfate, instead of the deposition of NH4HSO4 on γ-Fe2O3. In light of the typical binary mixed oxide catalyst, Fe2O3-TiO2, Liu investigated its deNO x performance in the presence of SO2 [135]. It was found that the sulfation process drove the catalyst operation temperature window to shift ca. 50 °C towards higher temperature range. The as-formed chelating bidentate sulfate species with strong acidity enhanced the adsorption of NH3 at higher temperatures, whereas NO x adsorption was severely inhibited with the formation of reactive monodentate nitrate species consequently suppressed. That resulted in the activity loss at low temperatures. Similar phenomena were also observed for Fe/CNTS, the commonly used supported Fe2O3-based catalyst, that ferric sulfate constituted the major sulfate species accumulated on the catalyst surface, which enhanced the adsorption of NH3 species at the cost of the adsorption and activation of NO x [136]. Thus, the formation of key intermediates that closely corresponded to the excellent low-temperature activity was interfered. As a result, a loss in the catalyst low-temperature (<275 °C) activity was caused. On the other hand, the as-formed sulfate anions would serve as the extra acid sites, which promoted the reaction between the adsorbed NH3 and gaseous NO, hence ensuring a satisfactory NO x reduction performance at higher temperatures. Further, Yang investigated the impacts of SO2 on the SCR reaction of Fe-Cu-O x /CNTs-TiO2 and FeCuO x /TiO2-hBN catalysts at different temperature points [137,138]. It was discovered that at a relatively low temperature point (<300 °C for Fe-Cu-O x /CNTs-TiO2 and <325 °C for FeCuO x /TiO2-hBN), the formed sulfite and sulfate species would cover the surface active sites and thus suppressed the adsorption and oxidation of NH3 and NO, consequently causing a severe sulfur-deactivation. As the reaction temperature was raised above 350 °C, the still inhibited NH3 adsorption could minimize the unwanted side reaction of NH3 oxidation, leaving most reductant available to react with NO x . Besides, the adsorption of NO would be conversely promoted, which consequently brought out an increment in the NO x conversion from 68% to 80%. By contrast, for Fe2O3-V2O5 binary mixed oxide catalyst, as the sulfation temperature increased, the deactivation originated from SO2 became worse because of the continuously lowered redox behavior and NO x activation ability [139]. As is mentioned above, sulfur poisoning is an important issue that should be addressed for the potentially practical applications of Fe2O3-based catalysts. To enhance the SO2-tolerant ability, introducing a foreign metal oxide to optimize the chemical features of the catalysts is welcome as an appropriate method. Liu found that in the presence of 100 ppm SO2, Fe/AC catalyst suffered from severe deactivation; only ∼50% NO x conversion was maintained after the exposure in the SO2-containing flue gas for 12 h [140]. With the modification of 0.5% V, the NO x conversion value increased to ∼93% after the SO2-deactivation cycle, demonstrating an enhanced sulfur-resistant capability of V2O5-doped catalyst. Yang found that Ti4+ in Ti-doped Fe2O3 catalyst was capable of attracting electrons from Fe3+ and intensified the electron-deficient extent of Fe3+, which drove Fe3+ to preferentially adsorb NH3 instead of SO2 and thus prevent the catalyst active centers from being deactivated by SO2 [141]. As a consequence, Ti-doped Fe2O3 catalysts presented an improved SO2-resistant ability that only 10% NO x conversion dropped during the SO2-dactivation process for the optimized Ti0.07-Fe2O3 catalyst, much less than that of pristine Fe2O3. Considering the acidic properties of SO2, Jin used H3WP12O40 to modify Fe2O3 nanoflowers [142]. Relying on its extraordinarily strong acidity, doping H3WP12O40 was able to bring out an enhanced acidity as well as a weakened oxidative ability, which, to a certain extent, suppressed the adsorption and the oxidation of SO2, thereby endowing H3WP12O40-promoted Fe2O3 catalyst with an improved sulfur resistance. A similar idea was also used by Ren that with the addition of WO3, an acidic metal oxides, sulfur tolerance of Fe2O3/ZrO2 catalyst was significantly enhanced; in the presence of 100 ppm, NO x conversion of WO3-promoted catalyst remained approximately 94% after 8 h, ∼50% higher than that of Fe2O3/ZrO2 [92]. Through DFT analysis, it was discovered that SO2 and H2O were adsorbed onto γ-Fe2O3 via weak chemical adsorption [143]. The doping of Mn was found to be beneficial for the formation of SO3, whereas the introduction of Co and Ce increased the activation energies of SO2 oxidation over γ-Fe2O3 surfaces, especially for Ce doping (Fig. 17 ). This endowed Ce-modified γ-Fe2O3 catalyst with an improved SO2-tolerant ability. Other systems, such as SmO x -Fe2O3 [144], Ce(SO4)2/α-Fe2O3 [145], Fe2O3-PrO x − MnO2/TiO2 [146], Fe2O3 Nb2O5-TiO2 [147], Fe2O3 CeO2-V2O5 [131], Fe2O3-Sb2O5 [148], and meso‑TiO2@Fe2O3@Al2O3 catalysts [149], also presented a certain sulfur-tolerant ability because of the promoted decomposition of NH4HSO4, the inhibited adsorption of SO2 onto the active sites, or the suppressed sulfation of the active species arising from the shielding effects of the introduced components. In addition to the modification of the formula, optimizing the preparation methods and the physicochemical properties of the supports were also considered as the effective methods to address this SO2-poisoning problem. Compared with the Mn-Fe/ZSM-5 synthesized using the co-precipitation method, catalyst prepared via the precipitation-chemical vapor deposition method had an excellent catalytic performance in the presence of SO2 and H2O based on the dynamic balance of the deposition and decomposition of ammonium sulfates [150]. Benefiting from the superior confinement characteristic of TiO2 nanotubes, the active species, Fe2O3, attached to the inner surface of the support could be protected from being poisoned by SO2, thus maintaining a relatively high NO x conversion in the presence of SO2 [151]. On the basis of the layered structures of MoO3, NH4 + in ammonia bisulfate would be intercalated into the interlayers of MoO3, which led to the separation of NH4 +-HSO4 − [152]. With the guidance of Fe2O3, the separated NH4 + could function as the reductant to reduce NO x . The remaining HSO4 − played the part of the redox sites to re-oxidize the reduced cations with SO2 released from the catalyst surfaces. As a result, Fe2O3/MoO3 catalyst was capable of stably removing NO x from the SO2-containing flue gas for a long time. Dong declared that as the pore size was increased from 4.8 nm to 11.8 nm, temperature for the decomposition of NH4HSO4 decreased by approximately 40 °C. That is to say, for the catalysts with a relatively large pore size, the deposition of NH4HSO4 seemed to be somehow difficult. As a result, Fe/SBA-15 catalyst with larger mesopores exhibited an improved sulfur resistance [153]. Alkaline metal species Alkaline metal species, including Na and K compounds, constituted the typical components in fly ash, especially in the power plants with high-alkaline-content coals combusted. Thus, the impacts of these species and the corresponding anti-poisoning abilities were also of great importance for the stable long-run operation of the Fe2O3-based catalysts. Liu found that the addition of K species led to the decrease in the deNO x activity of α-Fe2O3 catalyst; at a temperature of >350 °C, even negative NO x conversion was obtained. And given an increase in the introducing amount of K, <20% NO x conversion was presented within the whole explored temperature range [154]. Further, Niu investigated the K- and Na-poisoning mechanisms of α-Fe2O3 [155]. In the presence of K or Na, the strength of Bronsted acid sites were significantly reduced and the adsorption capacity of O2 was suppressed, which inhibited the adsorption of NH3 and the proceeding of the "fast-SCR" process. Besides, K or Na species inhibited the formation of H2O, the rate-determining step in the SCR reaction over α-Fe2O3, which predominantly explained this catalyst's declined SCR activity. Similarly, given that Fe-BEA catalyst was exposed in the K-containing flue gas, its deNO x activity also presented a tendency of decline due to the fact that iron species were lost through the exchange of iron species by K cations [156].
