On the contrary, adding limited amount of K or Na species caused negligible variations in the deNO x activity of Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst [157]. This phenomenon might be attributed to the plentiful strong acid sites on the ZSM-5 surface, which completely eliminated the negative impact regarding the consumption of acid sites by the insufficient alkaline species. Interestingly, for Fe/Beta system, a lower deposition of K species was able to facilitate the transfer of electrons and increased the content of Fe2+ and reducible Fe species, which even promoted the adsorption and oxidation of NO, thus improving the deNO x reactions [158]. With the deposition amount of K species increasing, the occupation of Bronsted acid sites, the aggregation of active Fe species, and the generation of inert nitrates seriously restricted the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Similar conclusions were also drawn by Jouini that the excessive deposition of K and Na caused the serious deactivation of FeCu-ZSM-5 [159]. In accordance of these results, Tang used the acidic WO3 to support Fe2O3 [160]. Relying on the superior acidity of WO3, Fe2O3 would be protected from being coordinated with K species, which exhibited an improved stability in the presence of K. On the basis of this system, Chen explored the effect of template agents, including urea, ethlyene glycol, polyvinyl alcohol, and hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide, on the catalyst alkali-tolerant ability, respectively [161]. Compared with other template agents, Fe2O3-WO3 catalyst synthesized using urea (FW-(urea)) showed a superior deNO x activity in the presence of K species. This was because K species tended to be aggregated over FW-(urea) and left abundant Fe sites still exposed; the improved acidity, superior redox ability, and more surface adsorbed oxygen species assured the efficient adsorption and activation of the reactants, thus enabling FW-(urea) catalyst with an improved anti-K poisoning ability compared with the parallel catalysts. Zhang even used Fe2(SO4)3/TiO2 catalyst to obtain a satisfactory K-resistant ability [162]. Sulfate groups in the catalysts with conserved surface species tended to migrate from the bulk to the surface, which effectively interacted with K species with iron active sites reserved. Given the coupling of the migrated sulfate species and active iron sites, adsorption and activation of NH3 and NO could also be well proceeded, thus still exhibiting a satisfactory deNO x activity between 200 and 500 °C (Fig. 18 ). Apart from these, the modification of CoO x [163], Nb2O5 [164], and PO4 3− [165] were also capable of resulting in an enhanced alkaline-resistant ability relying on the shielding effects of these foreign species on K species. Other poisoners Apart from the above-mentioned SO2 and alkaline metal species, some other poisoners in the flue gas, such as alkaline earth metal species, heavy metals, HCl, and P compounds, etc., also deactivated catalysts to different extents. Wang used the experimental method to investigate the effects of Ca species, the typical alkaline earth metal species, on the SCR performance of Fe-Ce/Ti catalysts [166,167]. It was claimed that with the addition of Ca(OH)2 and CaCO3, the specific surface area, the ratio of Fe3+ and Ce4+, the surface acidity and redox ability, and the amount of chemisorbed oxygen decreased, which had an inhibitory effect on the adsorption and activation of the reactants and mainly explained the declined NO x conversion of the catalysts. Furthermore, Sun employed the DFT method to study the Ca poisoning mechanism on the SCR reactions over the γ-Fe2O3 (001) surface. It was discovered that Ca atom had a high adsorption energy on the surface of γ-Fe2O3 (001), covering the catalyst surface and reducing the active sites. The presence of Ca atoms also decreased the adsorption performance of NH3 and restrained the activation of NH3 and the formation of NH2, which illustrated the reasons for the deactivation by Ca species from the microscopic perspective. Later, Sun found that adding Ce brought extra Lewis acid sites and transformed the inert nitrite/nitrate species to active ones [168]. Besides, the dehydrogenation of NH3 to NH2 was also boosted with the guidance of Ce, which, to some extent, enhanced the Ca-tolerant ability of γ-Fe2O3 (001). When it referred to Pb, a heavy metal commonly existing in industrial exhaust gas, Sun found that the addition of Pb led to a decrease in the high-valance-state metal cation content, lattice oxygen concentration, and acidity, which, as a result, did harm to the reduction performance of NO x [169]. Given that cobalt species were introduced, the interaction between Pb and lattice oxygen was weakened, which increased the amount of the above-mentioned active species and thus elevated the anti-Pb poisoning ability of 3Mn10Fe/Ni catalyst. Based on these ideas, the resistance to Pb poisoning of Mn/Fe-pillared catalysts was also effectively elevated though modifying cobalt species [170]. Interestingly, NO x conversion of >90% was still achieved in the temperature range of 225–400 °C even with the loading amount of Pb reaching 20 wt% for Fe-Mo binary mixed oxide [171]. The Bronsted acid sites in this system captured Pb to form PbMoO4 compounds with Lewis acid sites and redox properties barely affected. Besides, the as-produced PbMoO4 compounds were able to boost the activation of the reactants, which constituted the origin of the strong resistance against Pb. For the effects of phosphate and HCl on the activity of Fe2O3-based SCR catalysts, just limited studies were available. Given the introduction of P, deNO x performance of Cu-SSZ-13 was completely suppressed resulting from the disruption of the zeolite framework, the formation of CuO, and the reduction in the number of isolated Cu2+ ions [172]. Similarly, Courtois found that the addition of phosphate moderately affected the exchanged Cu2+ species and directly interacted with copper, which was responsible for the deactivation towards the oxidation reaction and thus led to a declined deNO x activity [173]. Li found that in the presence of HCl, Fe2O3 catalyst would be easily deactivated arising from the consumption of active oxygen species and the formation of inert FeCl3-like compounds. Given that a layer of TiSi shell was coated onto Fe2O3 surface, catalyst active sites would be well protected from being deactivated by HCl, hence exhibiting a nearly unchaned deNOx activity in the HCl-containing flue gas [174]. As is mentioned above, with proper modification, catalyst anti-poisoning ability can be elevated to some extent. However, considering the existence of multi-poisoners in the flue gas, the coupling effects of these poisoners on the catalyst deNO x performance still needed to be investigated because of the harsh conditions in real exhaust gas. Conclusions and perspectives Based on the afore-mentioned studies, Fe2O3-based catalysts have been shown to exhibit satisfactory deNO x performance and anti-poisoning ability through the synergistic effects among the components; in most cases, >80% NO x removal efficiency can be achieved in the temperature range of 275–400 °C with or without poisoners, which lays a solid foundation for the commercialization of this catalyst system. In spite of the progress achieved on the Fe2O3-based deNO x catalysts, more researches still need to go further and deeper so as to obtain deNO x catalysts with satisfactory performance for actual operation in engineering. Future researches may cover the following aspects: (1) Novel Fe2O3-based catalysts with high combination features, including the satisfactory deNO x activity, high N2 selectivity, excellent tolerance to poisoning, etc., should be investigated. The combination features of the catalysts play a determined role in their value for commercialization. However, it still constitutes a huge challenge for synthesizing catalysts with novel combination features. Introducing foreign metal oxides forming mixed oxides and loading Fe2O3-based active species onto the surface of suitable carriers might be the two promising research directions. (2) More researches need to be conducted to apply the catalysts from laboratory to practical industry. Indeed, most of the performance and mechanistic studies reported in the literature are on the basis of the so-called "model" catalysts. These "model" samples are speculated to be the powder-like catalysts, whereas the commercial ones are always the monolithic catalysts. Therefore, the corresponding molding process should be developed. And the impacts of the molding methods and the molding agents on the performance of the monolithic catalysts should be extensively investigated so that a highly active catalyst can be developed. And notably, clean conditions (in the absence of any poisoners in the simulated flue gas) are always employed at lab-scale, which are also far from those relevant to real industrial application. Therefore, experiments at pilot-scale or even full-scale should be carried out to develop new catalysts suitable for commercial application and provide new data more directly related to "real" catalysts working under "real" conditions. (3) Provided that a "novel" catalyst that can stably operate under "real" conditions has been developed, the economic analysis should be carried out to gain an understanding in the cost of the system. Based on this result, some procedures during the catalyst preparation process can be appropriately optimized, such as the improvement in the molding method and the proper selection of the molding agents. Only in this way, the cost of the system can be reduced to a considerable extent with a satisfactory deNO x efficiency still retained. coredata.dc:description: The emission of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) from the coal-fired power plants poses a huge threat to human health and natural environment. The selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (SCR) has been proven to be a mature technology for the abatement of NO x . To be the crucial component, the performance of the catalysts plays a determined role during the deNO x process. Fe2O3-based catalysts, as one of the most effective catalysts for SCR, have been comprehensively researched and fruitful results are achieved. Therefore, the advances in the applications of Fe2O3-based catalysts for NO x reduction was overviewed in this work. Simply put, the fundamentals of Fe2O3, such as this metal oxide's crystal structures and the corresponding preparation methods, were first introduced. After that, the physicochemical features and deNO x performances of various catalysts, including virgin Fe2O3, Fe2O3-supported, and Fe2O3-containing mixed oxide systems, were summarized. Considering the variable flue gas conditions in coal-fired power plants, the effects of the typical components of SO2, HCl, H2O, and fly ash on the catalyst's NO x reduction activity were also evaluated and the results demonstrated that with proper modification, catalyst flue gas component adaptability could be availably improved. Furthermore, the possible NO x reduction pathways over the Fe2O3-based catalysts under various conditions were discussed with the key intermediates and the rate-controlling stages clarified. Finally, suggestions were raised that attention needed to be concentrated on developing new Fe2O3-based catalysts that was capable of stably operating in real coal-fired flue gas in following research.
coredata.dc:title: The development of Fe2O3-based catalysts used for the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3: A review
